Shenandoah_(band):
{{Short description|American country music group}} {{About|the country band Shenandoah founded in the 1980s|Arlo Guthrie's country band|Arlo Guthrie}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Shenandoah | image = Shenandoah July 2008 pose.jpg | caption = Shenandoah in July 2008. L-R: Mike Folsom, Stan Munsey, Jimmy Yeary, Jim Seales, Mike McGuire. | landscape = yes | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], U.S. | genre = [[country music|Country]] | years_active = 1984{{ndash}}1997, 2000{{ndash}}present | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia/CBS]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Liberty Records|Liberty]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], Free Falls, Cumberland Road Records, Foundry Records | spinoffs = [[Raybon Brothers]] | website = {{URL|http://www.shenandoahband.com/}} | current_members = [[Marty Raybon]]
Mike McGuire
Paul Sanders
Nicky Hines
Donnie Allen
Andrew Ishee | past_members = See [[#Band members|Band members]] }} '''Shenandoah''' is an American [[country music]] band founded in [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], in 1984 by [[Marty Raybon]] (lead vocals, [[acoustic guitar]]), Ralph Ezell ([[bass guitar]], backing vocals), Stan Thorn ([[keyboard instrument|keyboards]], backing vocals), Jim Seales ([[lead guitar]], backing vocals), and Mike McGuire ([[Drum kit|drums]], background vocals). Thorn and Ezell left the band in the mid-1990s, with Rocky Thacker taking over on bass guitar; Keyboardist [[Stan Munsey]] joined the line up in 1995, until his departure in 2018. The band split up in 1997 after Raybon left. Seales and McGuire reformed the band in 2000 with lead singer Brent Lamb, who was in turn replaced by [[Curtis Wright]] and then by [[Jimmy Yeary]]. Ezell rejoined in the early 2000s, and after his 2007 death, he was replaced by Mike Folsom. Raybon returned to the band in 2014.{{Cite web|url = http://theboot.com/marty-raybon-shenandoah/|title = Marty Raybon Rejoins Shenandoah|date = 2014-08-28|access-date = 2014-09-05|website = The Boot|publisher = Taste of Country Network|last = Stefano|first = Angela}} That same year, Jamie Michael replaced the retiring Jim Seales on lead guitar. Shenandoah has released nine [[studio album]]s, of which two have been certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. The band has also charted twenty-six [[single (music)|singles]] on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including the Number One hits "[[The Church on Cumberland Road]]," "[[Sunday in the South]]" and "[[Two Dozen Roses]]" from 1989, "[[Next to You, Next to Me]]" from 1990, and "[[If Bubba Can Dance (I Can Too)]]" from 1994. The late 1994-early 1995 single "[[Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart]]," which featured guest vocals from [[Alison Krauss]], won both artists a [[Grammy Award]] for [[Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]]. == History == [[File:Shenandoah1994.png|200px|left|thumb|The original lineup as depicted in ''Modern Screen's Country Music'' magazine, August 1994. Top, L-R: Stan Thorn, Marty Raybon, Jim Seales. Bottom: Mike McGuire (left) and Ralph Ezell.]] [[Lead guitar]]ist Jim Seales and [[drummer]] Mike McGuire formed Shenandoah in 1984 as a house band in [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], with [[bass guitar]]ist Ralph Ezell and [[keyboardist]] Stan Thorn, as well as lead singer [[Marty Raybon]], who had been in his father's [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] band since childhood called American Bluegrass Express, as well as Heartbreak Mountain. Before that, Seales, Thorn, McGuire and Ezell were session musicians.{{cite web |url=http://www.gibson.com/player/apr03/raybon.html |title=Marty Raybon scratches his bluegrass itch |access-date=2009-10-12 |last=Nikolai |first=Michelle |work=Gibson Guitar Corporation |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719161854/http://www.gibson.com/player/apr03/Raybon.html |archive-date=2008-07-19 }} McGuire invited songwriting friend [[Robert Byrne (songwriter)|Robert Byrne]] to one of the session band's shows. Byrne then invited them into his recording studio to record a [[demo (music)|demo]], which he then pitched to [[Columbia Records]]' CBS Records division.{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1806|pure_url=yes}} |title=Shenandoah biography |access-date=2008-07-28 |last=Bush |first=John |work=[[Allmusic]]}} The band first wanted to assume the name The MGM Band, a name which was rejected for legal reasons. CBS suggested Rhythm Rangers and Shenandoah as possible names,{{cite book|last=Stambler|first=Irwin|author2=Grelun Landon |title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|publisher=Macmillan|year=2000|pages=435–436|isbn=0-312-26487-9}} and Raybon chose the latter because he thought that the name Rhythm Rangers "sounded like an amateur band." ===1987{{ndash}}1990: ''Shenandoah'' and ''The Road Not Taken''=== In 1987, Shenandoah released its [[Shenandoah (album)|self-titled]] debut [[studio album]], which Byrne and [[Rick Hall]] produced. This album accounted for the band's first two charting [[Single (music)|singles]] in "They Don't Make Love Like We Used To" and "Stop the Rain".{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|author-link=Joel Whitburn|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=378|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} The latter was the band's first Top 40 country hit, peaking at number 28 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. John Bush of [[Allmusic]] wrote that this album "leaned a little close to the [[pop music|pop]]-schmaltz they later rebelled against." ''[[The Road Not Taken (Shenandoah album)|The Road Not Taken]]'' was the band's second album, released in 1988. This album's first two singles — "[[She Doesn't Cry Anymore]]", previously found on ''Shenandoah'', and "[[Mama Knows]]" — brought the band to the Top Ten for the first time. After these singles came three consecutive ''Billboard'' number-one hits: "[[The Church on Cumberland Road]]", "[[Sunday in the South]]" and "[[Two Dozen Roses]]". "The Church on Cumberland Road," with its two-week run at Number One, marked the first time in country music history that a country music band's first number-one single spent more than one week at the top.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24532409.html?dids=24532409:24532409&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+28%2C+1989&author=Jack+Hurst%2C+Country+music+writer.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Folks%27+music+Shenandoah+strives+to+keep+its+common+touch&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120715073826/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24532409.html?dids=24532409:24532409&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+28,+1989&author=Jack+Hurst,+Country+music+writer.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Folks'+music+Shenandoah+strives+to+keep+its+common+touch&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 15, 2012|title=Folks' music Shenandoah strives to keep its common touch|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=1989-05-28|work=Chicago Tribune (subscription required)|access-date=2009-10-08}} This song was originally recorded by one of its three writers, former [[The Rockets (Detroit band)|Rockets]] and [[Billy Hill (band)|Billy Hill]] member [[Dennis Robbins]] as the [[B-side]] to his 1987 single "[[Two of a Kind, Workin' on a Full House]]"; [[Garth Brooks]] would later reach number one in 1991 with a rendition of the latter song.Whitburn, p. 354 Byrne co-wrote "Two Dozen Roses" with [[Mac McAnally]], a veteran songwriter and session musician who has recorded both as a solo singer and as a member of [[Jimmy Buffett]]'s Coral Reefer Band. The last single from ''The Road Not Taken'', "[[See If I Care (song)|See If I Care]]", reached number 6 on ''Billboard'' and number one on ''[[Gavin Report]]''. On January 22, 1991, ''The Road Not Taken'' earned a gold [[music recording sales certification|certification]] from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) for shipments of 500,000 copies in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Shenandoah&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130201195913/http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Shenandoah&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-02-01 |title=RIAA — Shenandoah albums |access-date=2008-07-06 |work=Recording Industry Association of America }} Tom Roland of [[Allmusic]] gave ''The Road Not Taken'' four-and-a-half stars out of five, with his review saying, "The songs mix the day-to-day struggles of everyday-Joe with a steady respect for love, personal roots, and family."{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r94026|pure_url=yes}}|title=''The Road Not Taken'' review|last=Roland|first=Tom|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-07}} In the wake of ''The Road Not Taken'''s success, the band played 300 shows in 1989.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HysLAAAAIBAJ&pg=4804,1139124&dq=shenandoah+marty-raybon&hl=en|title=Shenandoah is like family|last=Wescotte|first=Diane|date=1990-11-20|work=The Bryan Times ([[Google News]] archive)|access-date=2009-10-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ===1990{{ndash}}1992: ''Extra Mile'' and lawsuits=== The band achieved its biggest hit in 1990 with the three-week number-one single "[[Next to You, Next to Me]]." Written by then-solo singers [[Robert Ellis Orrall]] and [[Curtis Wright]],{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=song|id=t933323|pure_url=yes}}|title="Next to You, Next to Me" listing|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} this was the first of five singles from Shenandoah's third album, ''[[Extra Mile (album)|Extra Mile]]''. "[[Ghost in This House]]," "[[I Got You (Shenandoah song)|I Got You]]" (co-written by Teddy Gentry of the band [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]) and "[[The Moon Over Georgia]]" all peaked in the ''Billboard'' top ten between late 1990 and mid-1991, with the latter two reaching number one on ''Gavin Report''; "When You Were Mine," the fifth single, stopped at number 38 on ''Billboard'' in 1991. Also that year, the band won the [[Academy of Country Music]]'s Vocal Group of the Year award. [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave ''Extra Mile'' a B rating, saying that it was "unflinchingly commercial" but adding that "the band goes beyond Alabama's [[jingoism|jingoistic]] flag-waving and [[Restless Heart]]'s vapid mood-brighteners to showcase intelligent ballads and jaunty rhythm numbers."{{cite magazine|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,363792,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070331233615/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,363792,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 31, 2007|title=''Extra Mile'' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2009-10-08}} An uncredited review in the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' said that the band "proved that no matter how overcrowded the field is, there's always room for quality."{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADE6E033C47095&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Shenandoah goes that "Extra Mile"|date=1990-07-08|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (subscription required)|pages=G3|access-date=2009-10-08}} ''Extra Mile'' earned a gold certification in the United States. Following the release of ''Extra Mile'', a band from Kentucky threatened to sue Shenandoah over the use of the name Shenandoah. After a financial settlement was made with the Kentucky band, two other bands filed lawsuits over Shenandoah's name. The lawsuits depleted the money earned by the band on the road, which led to the band asking the label and their production company to all pay one-third of their legal costs. The production company refused, and Shenandoah was forced to file for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] in early 1991{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CSTB&p_theme=cstb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB3733327749E23&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Shenandoah bankruptcy|date=1991-02-04|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|access-date=2009-10-07}} after paying more than 2 million dollars on court settlements and legal fees.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VxsQAAAAIBAJ&pg=6761,5036513&dq=shenandoah+marty-raybon&hl=en|title=Shenandoah battles back from bankruptcy|last=Edwards|first=Joe|date=1992-03-30|work=The Free-Lance Star (Google News archive)|access-date=2009-10-08}} Although the lawsuits allowed Shenandoah to keep its name, the bankruptcy filing terminated the contract with Columbia after a 1992 ''[[Greatest Hits (Shenandoah album)|Greatest Hits]]'' package.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r104965|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Greatest Hits'' review|last=Campbell|first=Al|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} The production company's officials then filed a lawsuit against the band, claiming that it had tried to void its agreement with them. After Shenandoah's departure, there were no other bands on Columbia's Nashville division; as a result, producer Larry Strickland assembled three musicians to create a new band called [[Matthews, Wright & King]] in an attempt to keep a commercially successful band on the label.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p30167|pure_url=yes}}|title=Matthews, Wright & King biography|last=Loftus|first=Johnny|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-10}} ===1992{{ndash}}1994: ''Long Time Comin''' and ''Under the Kudzu''=== In 1992, the band had moved to [[RCA Records]] Nashville, releasing ''[[Long Time Comin']]'' on it that year. This album was produced by Byrne and [[Keith Stegall]], a former solo singer best known for producing [[Alan Jackson]]'s albums. "[[Rock My Baby]]" (another Curtis Wright co-write) led off the single releases, reaching number 2 on ''Billboard'' and ''[[Radio & Records]]'' and number 1 on ''Gavin Report''. After it came the top 30 hits "Hey Mister (I Need This Job)" and "[[Leavin's Been a Long Time Comin']]", whose [[music video]] featured a guest appearance by Dallas Cowboy quarterback and NFL hall of famer Troy Aikman as ‘Cowboy Joe’. Also guest appearing was [[Eddy Arnold]].{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24380141.html?dids=24380141:24380141&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+19%2C+1993&author=Brad+Webber.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Country+chartbuster+Eddy+Arnold%2C+74%2C+is+back+on+the+road+and+shooting+for+another+hit&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023031653/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24380141.html?dids=24380141:24380141&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+19,+1993&author=Brad+Webber.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Country+chartbuster+Eddy+Arnold,+74,+is+back+on+the+road+and+shooting+for+another+hit&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 23, 2012|title=Country chartbuster Eddy Arnold, 74, is back on the road and shooting for another hit|last=Webber|first=Brad|date=1993-03-19|work=[[Chicago Tribune]] (subscription required)|access-date=2009-10-08}} The band was nominated as Vocal Group of the Year at the Academy of Country Music again in 1992. ''Long Time Comin''' received a three-and-a-half star rating from the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', whose Jack Hurst said that it was "an excellent brand of rural-toned [[blue-collar]] music."{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24319760.html?dids=24319760:24319760&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:FT&type=current&date=Jul+30%2C+1992&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Memos+-+n+Home+Entertainment.+Rave+recordings....++Jack+Hurst.&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023031735/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24319760.html?dids=24319760:24319760&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:FT&type=current&date=Jul+30,+1992&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Memos+-+n+Home+Entertainment.+Rave+recordings....++Jack+Hurst.&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 23, 2012|title=Memos – n Home Entertainment. Rave recordings.... Jack Hurst.|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=1992-07-30|work=Chicago Tribune|pages=6|access-date=2009-10-08}} Nash gave a B− rating in ''Entertainment Weekly'', where she said that the album had a more [[country pop]]-oriented sound than its predecessors, but commended the "sincerity" of Raybon's voice and the themes of "family and friendship."{{cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/1992/06/26/long-time-comin/|title=''Long Time Comin''' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2009-10-08}} ''[[Under the Kudzu]]'', Shenandoah's second RCA album, followed in 1993. It was produced by [[Don Cook]], who was also [[Brooks & Dunn]]'s producer at the time. "[[Janie Baker's Love Slave]]", written by "[[Burning Love]]" writer [[Dennis Linde]], was a top 15 ''Billboard'' hit from the album early that year. Next came "[[I Want to Be Loved Like That]]", which peaked at number three on ''Billboard'', number two on ''Gavin Report'' and number one on ''Radio & Records''. The album also included the band's fifth and final ''Billboard'' number-one hit, "[[If Bubba Can Dance (I Can Too)]]", which Raybon and McGuire wrote with veteran Nashville songwriter [[Bob McDill]] after a conversation about [[line dancing]] instructions at the local bar Shenandoah started in. "I'll Go Down Loving You," the last single from the album, spent eleven weeks on the ''Billboard'' charts and peaked at number 46, thus becoming the band's first single to miss the Top 40 since "They Don't Make Love Like We Used To" in 1987. Michael Corcoran of ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' called ''Under the Kudzu'' "their strongest album to date",{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D39F0CC56CEB&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Raw sound sparks Shenandoah's 'Kudzu'|last=Corcoran|first=Michael|date=1993-07-25|work=Dallas News|access-date=2009-10-08}} and Jack Hurst gave it three stars, saying, "Shenandoah carries most of this album with impassioned vocals rather than superior song content."{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24200800.html?dids=24200800:24200800&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:FT&type=current&date=Dec+09%2C+1993&author=Jack+Hurst.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Tempo+Recordings.&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120715001236/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24200800.html?dids=24200800:24200800&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:FT&type=current&date=Dec+09,+1993&author=Jack+Hurst.&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Tempo+Recordings.&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 15, 2012|title=Tempo Recordings|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=1993-12-09|work=Chicago Tribune|pages=7|access-date=2009-10-08}} ===1994{{ndash}}1995: ''In the Vicinity of the Heart'' and collaborations=== Columbia's parent company [[Sony Music Entertainment]] released ten of the band's Columbia songs in a ''[[Super Hits (Shenandoah album)|Super Hits]]'' compilation in May 1994,{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r229196|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Super Hits''|last=Campbell|first=Al|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} which was certified gold in 2002. Shenandoah also collaborated with country and bluegrass singer [[Ricky Skaggs]] on the 1994 [[Keith Whitley]] tribute ''[[Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album]]'', recording a [[cover version]] of Whitley's "All I Ever Loved Was You".{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r204660|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Keith Whitley: A Tribute Album''|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} Later in 1994, the band left RCA for [[Liberty Records]], then the name for the Nashville division of [[Capitol Records]]. RCA gave Liberty the [[master recording]]s for a nearly-completed album, to which Liberty added "[[Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart]]", a song featuring guest vocals from bluegrass musician [[Alison Krauss]]. Liberty released the album in November 1994 as ''[[In the Vicinity of the Heart]]'', with the number seven-peaking title track also serving as the first single release. This song was also Krauss' first top 40 country hit,{{cite news |title=A pure sound of success |author=David Zimmerman |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/19374453.html?dids=19374453:19374453&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+14%2C+1995&author=David+Zimmerman&pub=USA+TODAY+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=A+pure+sound+of+success+%2F%2F+Country+world+heeds+her+clear+siren+song&pqatl=google |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604041501/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/19374453.html?dids=19374453:19374453&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+14,+1995&author=David+Zimmerman&pub=USA+TODAY+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=A+pure+sound+of+success+%2F%2F+Country+world+heeds+her+clear+siren+song&pqatl=google |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 4, 2011 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=1995-08-14 |access-date=2010-01-17}} and its success helped boost sales of her album ''[[Now That I've Found You: A Collection]]''.{{cite news |title=Krauss follows instinct for success |author=Jim Patterson |newspaper=Lawrence Journal-World |date=1995-09-23 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5WoyAAAAIBAJ&pg=6749,2756282&dq=somewhere-in-the-vicinity-of-the-heart&hl=en |access-date=2010-01-17}} ''Vicinity'' became the band's fastest-selling album,{{cite magazine|last=Bessman|first=Jim|date=1995-09-30|title=Shenandoah enjoys resurgence|magazine=Billboard|pages=30 and 35|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ag4EAAAAMBAJ&q=shenandoah%20%22under%20the%20kudzu&pg=PA35}} and the first 175,000 copies were distributed with prepaid [[telephone card]]s which included an [[800 number]] that could be called to receive a greeting from the band members.{{cite magazine|last=Cronin|first=Peter|date=1994-12-10|title=Success in the Cards for Shenandoah|magazine=Billboard|pages=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZQgEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22in+the+vicinity+of+the+heart%22+shenandoah&pg=PA32}} The album also produced the band's last Top Ten hit in "[[Darned If I Don't (Danged If I Do)]]." Originally the [[B-side]] to "Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart," this song was co-written by [[Ronnie Dunn]] (of Brooks & Dunn) and songwriter [[Dean Dillon]],{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=song|id=t2947050|pure_url=yes}}|title=Darned If I Don't (Danged If I Do)|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} best known for co-writing several of [[George Strait]]'s singles. "[[Heaven Bound (I'm Ready)]]" (another Dennis Linde song) and "Always Have, Always Will," peaking at numbers 24 and 40, were the last two releases from the album. Jim Ridley gave the album a two-and-a-half star rating in ''New Country'' magazine, citing the vocal performances on the title track and "I Wouldn't Know" as standouts, but saying that the rest of the album did not take any risks.{{cite journal|last=Ridley|first=Jim|date=January 1995|title=Album reviews: ''In the Vicinity of the Heart''|journal=New Country|volume=2|issue=1|pages=57–58|issn=1074-536X}} Raybon released a solo [[gospel music]] album for [[Sparrow Records]] in July 1995,{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r227838|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Marty Raybon'' (1995)|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} and in October of the same year, that label released a multi-artist country-gospel album entitled ''Amazing Grace — A Country Salute to Gospel'', to which the band contributed a rendition of "[[Beulah Land]]."{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Grace-Country-Salute-Gospel/dp/B000005KXK|title=''Amazing Grace: A Country Salute to Gospel''|work=[[Amazon.com]]|access-date=2009-10-08}} Shenandoah also covered [[The Beatles]]' "[[Can't Buy Me Love]]" on the mid-1995 album ''[[Come Together: America Salutes The Beatles]]''.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r210538|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Come Together: America Salutes the Beatles''|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} "Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart" won Shenandoah and Krauss won the 1995 [[Grammy Award]] for Best Country Vocal Collaboration and the [[Country Music Association]] award for Vocal Event, and "Darned If I Don't" was nominated for Grammy Award for Best Country Vocal by a Duo or Group the same year. ===1995{{ndash}}1996: ''Now and Then'' and ''Shenandoah Christmas''=== Stan Thorn and Ralph Ezell left in late 1995 and early 1996, respectively, with Rocky Thacker unofficially replacing Ezell, and songwriter/keyboardist [[Stan Munsey]] replacing Thorn. During this time, Liberty Records was renamed Capitol Records Nashville. The band's first album for Capitol, 1996's ''Now and Then'', comprised re-recordings of eight Columbia singles, the original recording of "Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart", and five new songs. Among these new songs was the album's only single, "All Over but the Shoutin'," which peaked at number 43 on ''Billboard''. Nash gave this album an A− rating in ''Entertainment Weekly'', saying that Raybon's voice "beautifully capture[s] the [[rite of passage|rites of passage]] in Small Town, USA."{{cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/1996/04/05/now-and-then/|title=''Now and Then'' review|last=Nash|first=Alanna|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=2009-10-08}} Larry Stephens of ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' also reviewed the album favorably, saying, "The familiar hits on this album have all been re-recorded, but they've lost none of their familiar and loved sound,"{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2550|title=''Now and Then'' review|last=Stephens|first=Larry|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|access-date=2009-10-08}} while Allmusic critic William Ruhlmann gave it two stars out of five and referred to it as a "stopgap."{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r233471|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Now and Then'' review|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} Shenandoah's first [[Christmas music]] album, ''Shenandoah Christmas'', was released in September 1996, also on Capitol. Except for the original song "There's a Way in the Manger," it comprised [[acoustic music|acoustic]] renditions of popular Christmas songs.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/14829421.html?dids=14829421:14829421&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+15%2C+1996&author=ROGER+CATLIN%3B+Courant+Rock+Critic&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=CHRISTMAS+ALBUMS+COME+FROM+EVERY+MUSICAL+GENRE+MAKING+MERRY+MUSIC+FOR+THE+HOLIDAYS&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024181815/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/14829421.html?dids=14829421:14829421&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+15,+1996&author=ROGER+CATLIN%3B+Courant+Rock+Critic&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=CHRISTMAS+ALBUMS+COME+FROM+EVERY+MUSICAL+GENRE+MAKING+MERRY+MUSIC+FOR+THE+HOLIDAYS&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 24, 2012|title=Christmas albums from every musical genre making merry music for the holidays|last=Catlin|first=Roger|date=1996-12-15|work=[[Hartford Courant]] (subscription required)|pages=G1|access-date=9 January 2010}} It received a two-and-a-half star rating from Allmusic, whose critic Thom Owens said that none of the renditions were "particularly noteworthy."{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r241057|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Shenandoah Christmas'' review|last=Owens|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} ===1997: Departure of Marty Raybon and disbanding of Shenandoah=== [[File:Raybon.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Marty Raybon at [[CMA Music Festival]], June 2010.]] Marty Raybon and his brother Tim recorded one album as the [[Raybon Brothers]] for [[MCA Nashville Records]] in mid-1997. They charted within the top 40 on both the country and [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] charts with a rendition of the [[Bob Carlisle]] song "[[Butterfly Kisses (song)|Butterfly Kisses]]," followed by the number 64 country release "The Way She's Lookin'."Whitburn, p. 340 Marty continued to tour with Shenandoah until the end of the year,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ec0UAAAAIBAJ&pg=4408,4765530&dq=raybon-brothers&hl=en|title=Horse Party! Shenandoah headlines the first ever 'Celebration of the Horse'|last=Dunn|first=J. A.|date=1997-10-10|work=Ocala Star-Banner|access-date=2009-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160730004137/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ec0UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MAgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4408,4765530&dq=raybon-brothers&hl=en|archive-date=2016-07-30|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFE8055673C619&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Shenandoah heads for last roundup|last=Alexander|first=Wiley|date=1997-11-14|work=San Antonio Express-News|pages=32H|access-date=2009-10-08}} when the remaining members disbanded and he sold the naming rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1472893/solo-flight.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607022214/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1472893/solo-flight.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Solo Flight|last=Gray|first=Michael|date=2000-02-14|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=2009-10-08}} In 2000, he released a second solo album and charted his only solo country chart hit, the number 63 "Cracker Jack Diamond." Raybon remained a solo artist, while Thorn self-released a solo [[jazz]] album titled ''In a Curious Way'' in 2001.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r772594|pure_url=yes}}|title=''In a Curious Way''|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-12}} ===2000{{ndash}}present: Reunion and ''Shenandoah 2000''=== Seales, McGuire, Munsey and Thacker reunited as Shenandoah in 2000, with two new members: lead singer Brent Lamb,{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1476091/shenandoah-recruits-singer.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607022224/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1476091/shenandoah-recruits-singer.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Shenandoah Recruits Singer|date=2000-01-27|work=CMT|access-date=2009-10-08}} and guitarist/vocalist Curtis Wright, who was also playing with [[Pure Prairie League]] at the time.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r496765|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Shenandoah 2000'' credits|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} Before joining Shenandoah, Wright had been a member of the [[Super Grit Cowboy Band]] in the 1980s, then a solo artist and one-half of the duo [[Orrall & Wright]] with Robert Ellis Orrall.{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p31126|pure_url=yes}} |title=Curtis Wright Biography |access-date=2007-12-28 |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |work=[[Allmusic]]}} Wright also wrote "Next to You, Next to Me" and "Rock My Baby", collaborating with Orrall on the former. In 2000, the new lineup recorded the band's next album, ''Shenandoah 2000'', under the Free Falls label. It produced the band's last chart single in the number 65 "What Children Believe." Jolene Downs of [[About.com]] gave this album a positive review, saying that it was a "very strong country album" and "a slightly different sound from the original group, but not bad at all."{{cite web|url=http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blshenandoahrev.htm|title=''Shenandoah 2000'' review|last=Downs|first=Jolene|work=About.com|access-date=2009-10-24|archive-date=2012-01-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111070400/http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blshenandoahrev.htm|url-status=dead}} The band toured small venues in 2001 to promote it.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NT&s_site=duluthsuperior&p_multi=DU&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EDF832187C45989&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Shenandoah, band from Muscle Shoals, Ala., thrives on the road less taken|date=2001-08-17|work=Duluth News|access-date=2009-10-24}} Lamb left in 2002, with Wright succeeding him on lead vocals and original bassist Ralph Ezell later re-joining.{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050108094343/http://www.shenandoahband.com/|archive-date=2005-01-08|title=Shenandoah official website: "As seen in ''Country Weekly''"|url=http://www.shenandoahband.com/|author=Nick Krewen|work=Shenandoah official website|access-date=2009-10-08}} In 2006, Shenandoah released the album ''Journeys'' on the Cumberland Road label.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1103892|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Journeys''|work=Allmusic|access-date=2009-10-08}} Ezell died of a heart attack on November 30, 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1575878/shenandoah-bassist-ralph-ezell-dies.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606041602/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1575878/shenandoah-bassist-ralph-ezell-dies.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 6, 2009|title=Shenandoah bassist Ralph Ezell dies|date=2007-12-05|work=CMT|access-date=2009-10-08}} and Mike Folsom succeeded him on bass guitar. Also, Wright, after also finishing his stint in [[Pure Prairie League]] left the group to join [[Reba McEntire]]'s band in early 2007,{{cite web |url=http://archives.thepilot.com/September2004/09-24-04/092404RaiseRoof.html |title=Raise the Roof 5: Pure Prairie League Ready for Show |access-date=2008-01-01 |last=Smith |first=Stephen |date=2007-05-24 |work=The Pilot |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817191404/http://archives.thepilot.com/September2004/09-24-04/092404RaiseRoof.html |archive-date=2007-08-17 }} and songwriter [[Jimmy Yeary]] took over as lead singer.{{cite web|url=http://www.connecttristates.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=218998 |title=Blue Ryno Foundation benefit |last=Douglas |first=Chad |date=2008-11-07 |work=KHQA |publisher=Connect Tristates.com |access-date=2008-12-04 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524010904/http://www.connecttristates.com/news/news_story.aspx?id=218998 |archive-date=2011-05-24 }} In April 2009, the lineup of Yeary, Folsom, McGuire, Munsey and Seales performed a benefit concert in Muscle Shoals, in which Wright and Raybon also participated.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/article/20090402/ARTICLES/904025000/1004?Title=Together-again |title=Together again: Shenandoah, Raybon reunite for benefit |last=Corey |first=Russ |date=1 April 2009 |work=The Times-Daily |access-date=25 August 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Yeary and McGuire co-wrote a song entitled "You Never Know" as a tribute to Ezell. [[Darryl Worley]] recorded this song on his 2009 album ''[[Sounds Like Life]]'', saying that he considered it "dead-on" for him.{{cite journal|last=Scarlett|first=David|date=2009-06-22|title=Maybe the Hard Times Are Over|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=16|issue=19|pages=38–41|issn=1074-3235}} Shenandoah has continued to tour in 2009 and 2010 with Yeary on lead vocals, mostly playing at community festivals and [[county fair]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.marshalltribune.com/story/1578552.html|title=GMM shines in the rain|last=Confehr|first=Clint|date=2009-10-14|work=Marshall County Tribune|access-date=2009-10-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.shenandoahband.com/splash-page.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090613005336/http://www.shenandoahband.com/splash-page.php|url-status=dead|archive-date=2009-06-13|title=Tour schedule|work=Shenandoah official website|access-date=2009-10-24}} Yeary engaged country-gospel singer [[Sonya Isaacs]] (of [[The Isaacs]]) in November 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.gaither.com/events/newsdetail.php?newsid=108 |title=Gaither.com Interview with Sonya Isaacs on Her Engagement! |work=Gaither.com |access-date=2009-11-02 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091031070809/http://www.gaither.com/events/newsdetail.php?newsid=108 |archive-date=October 31, 2009 }} They have since become married and had one son in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/sonya-isaacs-jimmy-yeary-baby-boy/|title=Sonya Isaacs and Husband Jimmy Yeary Welcome a Baby Boy|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|date=July 26, 2011|work=Taste of Country|access-date=18 May 2012}} He has also written songs for other artists, including "[[In Another World (song)|In Another World]]" by [[Joe Diffie]], "[[Why Wait (song)|Why Wait]]" by [[Rascal Flatts]], "Summer Thing" by [[Troy Olsen]], "[[I'm Gonna Love You Through It]]" by [[Martina McBride]], and "[[I Drive Your Truck]]" by [[Lee Brice]]. Yeary left in 2011, with Doug Stokes taking over on lead vocals, and Chris Lucas (Roach) on bass.{{cite web|url=http://www.myplainview.com/news/article_1182a9e0-1290-11e3-8348-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Shenandoah playing for Cotton Barons|date=31 August 2014|work=MyPlainview.com|access-date=29 August 2014}} In August 2014, Marty Raybon re-joined as lead singer of the band, replacing Doug Stokes. At the time of his rejoining, the band consists of Raybon, McGuire, Munsey, and bassist Chris Lucas, later replaced by Paul Sanders.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/marty-raybon-reunites-with-shenandoah-after-17-years-20140827|title=Marty Raybon Reunites With Shenandoah After Almost Two Decades|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=August 27, 2014}} In October, Jamie Michael replaced the retiring Jim Seales on lead guitar. In 2016, Brad Benge joined the group on bass and baritone vocals, until his departure in 2018. In February 2016, Shenandoah signed with Johnstone Entertainment for management representation. "The confidence that you place in a person should be based on the true understanding you have of their integrity, wisdom and vision. We feel we made the right decision with Cole Johnstone as our manager as we set our sights on the future." said lead vocalist Marty Raybon {{Cite news|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/150807/shenandoah-signs-with-johnstone-entertainment-for-|title=Shenandoah Signs With Johnstone Entertainment For Management|work=All Access|access-date=2017-11-02|language=en}} The band released a collaborative album in 2020 titled ''Every Road'', which featured vocal collaborations with country music artists such as [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Luke Bryan]]. "Then a Girl Walks In", a duet with [[Blake Shelton]], served as the lead single. This was followed in 2023 by the band announcing they would begin a 50-show Revival Tour in early 2023.{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/shenandoah-2023-revival-tour-dates/ | title=Shenandoah Plan Extensive Revival Tour for 2023 | publisher=Taste of Country | date=February 9, 2023 | accessdate=February 12, 2023}} Coinciding with this tour was a single titled "Revival", which was co-written by both members of [[Florida Georgia Line]].{{cite web | url=https://themusicuniverse.com/shenandoah-preps-uplifting-revival/ | title=Shenandoah preps uplifting 'Revival' | publisher=Music Universe | date=January 26, 2023 | accessdate=February 12, 2023}} In September 2023, Shenandoah recorded a new version of "Two Dozen Roses" with [[Luke Combs]]. Released via 8 Track Entertainment, the track was recorded at the historic [[FAME Studios]] in Muscle Shoals, Alabama and was produced by [[Grammy Awards]] winning producer Noah Gordon. [[Billboard (magazine)]] premiered the track on September 21, 2023.{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/luke-combs-shenandoah-two-dozen-roses-collaboration-1235416689/ | title=Listen: Luke Combs & Shenandoah Refresh Shenandoah's Classic 'Two Dozen Roses' [Premiere] | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }} Upon release, "Two Dozen Roses" hit #1 on the [[iTunes]] All Genre and Country Charts.{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/industry-ink-shenandoah-clay-walker-lady-luck-songs-more/ | title=Industry Ink: Shenandoah, Clay Walker, Lady Luck Songs, More | date=3 November 2023 }} ==Musical styles== The band's sound is defined by country, bluegrass and gospel influences. John Bush of Allmusic calls Shenandoah "one of the first groups to rebel against the [[Urban Cowboy|urban cowboy]] image of the '80s and lead the way to the [[neotraditionalist country|new traditionalism]] of the '90s." Marty Raybon's vocals have been described as "blend[ing] the soulfulness of [[rhythm and blues]] with the lonely intensity of great country music."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2dISAAAAIBAJ&pg=2437,2778584&dq=shenandoah+marty-raybon&hl=en|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120713085315/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2dISAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IvwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2437,2778584&dq=shenandoah+marty-raybon&hl=en|url-status=dead|archive-date=2012-07-13|title=Shenandoah|date=1992-03-04|work=[[The Ledger]]|access-date=2009-10-09}} Alanna Nash wrote that the band's work relies on "sentimental lyrics revolving around the Southern experience," and said that Shenandoah "forged its very commercial reputation on a soulful [[gospel music|gospel]]-and-[[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] blend, with lead singer Marty Raybon's searing sincerity making even the tritest songs about small-town Southern values and attitudes memorable." Logan Smith of the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' said that the band has "woven together a highly polished sound built around precision musicianship and pristine harmonies, very much a hybrid of Raybon's bluegrass roots."{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/21305617.html?dids=21305617:21305617&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+25%2C+1995&author=LOGAN+NEILL&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&desc=Shenandoah+soars+Series%3A+Page+Three&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130201032614/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/21305617.html?dids=21305617:21305617&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+25,+1995&author=LOGAN+NEILL&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&desc=Shenandoah+soars+Series:+Page+Three&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 1, 2013|title=Shenandoah soars |last=Smith|first=Logan|date=1995-08-25|work=St. Petersburg Times|page=3|access-date=2009-10-16}} Writing for the [[Associated Press]], Joe Edwards cited the variety of sounds on the band's second album, referring to "The Church on Cumberland Road" as a "spirited up-tempo," also making note of the Southern imagery in "Sunday in the South" and the "truest country music tradition" of the ballad "She Doesn't Cry Anymore."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ee8aAAAAIBAJ&pg=6817,82820&dq=marty-raybon+shenandoah&hl=en|title=Shenandoah climbing toward peak of country music success|last=Edwards|first=Joe|date=1989-09-01|work=Daily News|pages=10|access-date=2010-01-09}} ==Band members== ===Current=== *[[Marty Raybon]] – lead vocals, acoustic guitar (1984–1997, 2014–present) *Mike McGuire – [[drum kit|drums]], backing vocals (1984–1997, 2000–present) *Donnie Allen – fiddle, acoustic guitar (1990–1997, 2014–present) *Paul Sanders – bass guitar, backing vocals (2014–2016, 2018–present) *Austin Brown – lead guitar (2024–present) ===Former=== *Ralph Ezell – bass guitar, backing vocals (1984–1996, 2002–2007; died 2007) *Jim Seales – [[lead guitar]], backing vocals (1984–1997, 2000–2014) *Stan Thorn – keyboards, backing vocals (1984–1995) *Rocky Thacker – bass guitar, backing vocals (1996–1997, 2000–2002) *Brent Lamb – lead vocals, acoustic guitar (2000–2002) *[[Curtis Wright]] – lead and backing vocals, acoustic guitar (2000–2007) *Mike Folsom – bass guitar, backing vocals (2007–2011) *[[Jimmy Yeary]] – lead vocals, [[acoustic guitar]] (2007–2011) *Doug Stokes – lead vocals (2011–2014) *Travis Mobley – keyboards (2018–2022) *Chris Lucas (Roach) – bass guitar (2011–2014) *Brad Benge – bass guitar, backing vocals (2016–2018) *[[Stan Munsey]] – keyboards (1995–1997, 2000–2018) *Jamie Michael – lead guitar, backing vocals (2014–2020) *Jeff Allen – bass guitar, backing vocals (2010–2011) *Austin Crum – lead guitar (2020–2022) *Nicky Hines – lead guitar (2022–2024) *Andrew Ishee – keyboards (2022–2024) == Discography == {{Main|Shenandoah discography}} ===Studio albums=== *''[[Shenandoah (album)|Shenandoah]]'' (1987) *''[[The Road Not Taken (Shenandoah album)|The Road Not Taken]]'' (1989) *''[[Extra Mile (album)|Extra Mile]]'' (1990) *''[[Long Time Comin']]'' (1992) *''[[Under the Kudzu]]'' (1993) *''[[In the Vicinity of the Heart]]'' (1994) *''Shenandoah Christmas'' (1996) *''Shenandoah 2000'' (2000) *''Journeys'' (2006) *Good Ole Fashioned Christmas (2014) *''Good News Travels Fast'' (2016) *''Reloaded'' (2018) *''Every Road'' (2020) ===''Billboard'' number-one hits=== *"[[The Church on Cumberland Road]]" (2 weeks, 1989) *"[[Sunday in the South]]" (1 week, 1989) *"[[Two Dozen Roses]]" (1 week, 1989) *"[[Next to You, Next to Me]]" (3 weeks, 1990) *"[[If Bubba Can Dance (I Can Too)]]" (1 week, 1994) ==Awards and nominations== === Grammy Awards === {{awards Vocal]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2| [[38th Grammy Awards|1996]] |"[[Darned If I Don't (Danged If I Do)]]" |{{nom}} |- |"[[Somewhere in the Vicinity of the Heart]]"{{Ref|1|[A]}} |[[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]] |{{won}} |} === American Music Awards === {{awards table}} |- |[[American Music Awards of 1991|1991]] |Shenandoah |[[American |Vocal Band of the Year |{{nom}} |- |[[30th TNN/Music City News Country Awards|1996]] |Shenandoah and [[Alison Krauss]] |Vocal Collaboration of the Year |{{nom}} |} === Academy of Country Music Awards
